question: A microbiome is the collection of genomes of all the microorganisms found in a particular environment. Some examples are all the bacteria, fungi, protozoa, and viruses that live on and inside the human body microbiome.
The microbiome in the gut can be radically different from the microbiota that strives on the skin.
The human body is, in fact, a “supraorganism”: a collection of human and microbial cells and genes. And thus, a blend of human and microbial traits.
